ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Close reading/literary analysis and essay writing skills. I also got an introduction to the major literary works of the western canon.
Deepened my literary analysis skills and learned about movements in Western literature since Petrarch.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: DS literature is great, but I think that I suffered in this section because of all the extra work that was given in addition to papers and readings.

The focus on improving my essay writing process and general skills as a writer was very helpful, and the class discussions were also very engaging and deeply explored the texts we read. All of the one-on-one office hours before and after essays were extremely helpful in identifying areas for me to improve in essay writing and close reading. Sometimes feedback on essays took too long to receive though, and in the beginning of the semester the discussion post homework was a bit tedious, and thankfully that was reduced as the semester progressed.

I enjoyed the variety of texts and felt that they spoke to each other in fascinating ways. Professors had a great ability to explain the texts and I value the fact that they focused our discussions on how texts work, even if discussions sometimes tended towards more ethical evaluation of characters.
I loved this course and honestly wouldn't change a thing.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual discussion format worked very well, and the transition to virtual format worked surprisingly well this year for DS literature.
I appreciated the way they started class with a video.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend DS, but not this section.
Yes, the texts that we read are all amazing and worth discussing and analyzing, and I really feel that I've grown as a writer and improved at participating in discussion.
I would, yes. I enjoyed reading the works we studied in this course, the lectures were excellent, and Professors Slanski and Hodgkin were very good at highlighting the ways each work was unique.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
